subject: Re: Filtering does not appear to work in 4.3.1
msgSnippet: David, In order to support older JUnit execution environments (Ant, Eclipse) which need the 3.8 hooks, our classes have suite() methods. This appears to be the

David,

In order to support older JUnit execution environments (Ant, Eclips=
e)
which need the 3.8 hooks, our classes have suite() methods. 

This appea=
rs to be the deciding factor, and this is a clear change
from JUnit 4.1. Ad=
ding the suite() method appears to route execution
down a path that ignores=
 the JUnit 4.x hooks (OldTestClassRunner).

I have updated the bug to inclu=
de this data as well.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Schechter" <m=
lschechter@...> wrote:
>
> David,
> 
> I've created the bug (# 1739095). Pl=
ease let me know if you have any
> questions.
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> --- In juni=
t@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@> wrote:
> >
> > Michael,
> > 
> > I'=
ve been meaning to look at this for a while now.  At a very cursory
> > gla=
nce, it looks like it may be a bug.  Can you log it as a bug in
> > SourceF=
orge, and I'll try to take a look at it in the next few days?
> > Thanks,
>=
 > 
> >    David Saff
> > 
> > On 6/8/07, Michael Schechter <mlschechter@> =
wrote:
> > > Does anyone have any suggestions on how to address this?
> > >=

> > > Thanks!
> > >
> > > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Schechter=
" <mlschechter@>
> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Kent/David et. al.,
> > > >
> > >=
 > I have been successfully using a filter implementation that I
> provided=

> > > > with one or more method names. These methods were the only ones
> =
> > > executed in the test class. Worked seamlessly with 4.1
> > > >
> > > =
> I just recently updated to JUnit 4.3.1, and the filter
> implementation
>=
 > > > no longer seems to be applied. There is nothing I can find in the
> =
> > > release notes that implies that this would have changed. The
> > > > =
frustrating thing is that setting breakpoints in my filter has no
> > > > e=
ffect - it is as if it is never being called.
> > > >
> > > > I am includin=
g the filter implementation class and the invocation
> > > > logic. Please =
let me know if there is something I missed here.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks in =
advance!
> > > >
> > > > ------------------------------------------------
>=
 > > > import java.util.ArrayList;
> > > > import java.util.List;
> > > >
>=
 > > > import org.junit.runner.Description;
> > > > import org.junit.runner=
.manipulation.Filter;
> > > >
> > > > /**
> > > >  * This class provides a =
mechanism to filter tests by name,
> allowing a
> > > > subset of the tests=
 in a test
> > > >  * class to be defined by a developer.
> > > >  *
> > > =
>  * @since 2.0
> > > >  */
> > > > public class MatchingFilter extends Fil=
ter {
> > > >
> > > >   /**
> > > >    * The references to the tests that s=
hould be executed.
> > > >    */
> > > >   private List<Description> tests =
=3D new ArrayList<Description>();
> > > >
> > > >   /**
> > > >    * Initia=
lizes an instance of <code>MatchingFilter</code>
with the
> > > > data prov=
ided.
> > > >    *
> > > >    * @param aTestClass
> > > >    *          the=
 class for which tests will be executed
> > > >    * @param someTestNames
>=
 > > >    *          the method names
> > > >    */
> > > >   public Matchi=
ngFilter(Class aTestClass, String[]
someTestNames) {
> > > >     for (Strin=
g testName : someTestNames) {
> > > >       this.tests.add(Description.crea=
teTestDescription(aTestClass,
> > > > testName));
> > > >     }
> > > >   }=

> > > >
> > > >   /**
> > > >    * Implemented abstract method to provide =
detail filtering
> > > > mechanism. Only test methods that match
> > > >   =
 * the provided names will be executed.
> > > >    *
> > > >    * @see
> > =
> >
> > >
>
org.junit.runner.manipulation.Filter#shouldRun(org.junit.runner=
.Description)
> > > >    */
> > > >   @Override
> > > >   public boolean sh=
ouldRun(Description aDescription) {
> > > >     return this.tests.contains(=
aDescription);
> > > >   }
> > > >
> > > >   /**
> > > >    * Implemented a=
bstract method.
> > > >    *
> > > >    * @see org.junit.runner.manipulatio=
n.Filter#describe()
> > > >    */
> > > >   @Override
> > > >   public Stri=
ng describe() {
> > > >     return "This filter excludes any test methods t=
hat do not
> exactly
> > > > match the provided names";
> > > >   }
> > > >=

> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > ------------------------------------------------=

> > > >     JUnitCore core =3D new JUnitCore();
> > > >     Request testRe=
quest =3D Request.aClass(aTestClass);
> > > >     if (0 < someArguments.len=
gth) {
> > > >       Filter matchFilter =3D new MatchingFilter(aTestClass,
=
> > > someArguments);
> > > >       testRequest =3D testRequest.filterWith(=
matchFilter);
> > > >     }
> > > >     core.run(testRequest);
> > > >
> > =
> > ------------------------------------------------
> > > >
> > > >
> > > =
>
> > > > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Schechter" <bard@> wrote:
=
> > > > >
> > > > > Kent,
> > > > >
> > > > > First and foremost, thanks! T=
hat example did the trick. I was
> able to
> > > > > modify it, and our tea=
m can now specify any subset of the test
> methods
> > > > > in a given cla=
ss dynamically as part of their development
process.
> > > > >
> > > > > I =
would strongly recommend that this trick (and any others that
> > > > > req=
uire extension/implementation from JUnit core classes) be
> added to
> > > =
> > whatever "recipes" get documented.
> > > > >
> > > > > I feel very stro=
ngly about the utility of JUnit (or any
> similar tool)
> > > > > in a test=
ing-dependent development environment. The only
> drawback I
> > > > > can =
see to using volunteer labor for documentation purposes is
> that
> > > > >=
 these volunteers would need access to the brains behind the
> code to
> > =
> > > write complete Javadoc. For example, in following your
> example, I g=
ot
> > > > > tripped up by the Request filterWith() method. So many
framewo=
rks
> > > > > today return a modified instance of the class on which you ar=
e
> > > > > operating that I was somewhat surprised that the instance on
> =
which I
> > > > > called filterWith() was not modified.
> > > > >
> > > > >=
 Upon reflection, your contract and implementation are perfectly
> > > > > =
reasonable OO - the filtered instance is what is returned, not
> what is
> =
> > > > invoked. This is the kind of fine point that would be easy to
> mis=
s in
> > > > > documenting this code as a volunteer. I point this out not a=
s an
> > > > > argument against. Instead, those who volunteer must be
> cog=
nizant of
> > > > > the fairly subtle complexities of this framework, and b=
e
> willing to
> > > > > ask questions when contributing.
> > > > >
> > > >=
 > Once again, thanks for the timely assist!
> > > > >
> > > > > --- In jun=
it@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Mic=
hael,
> > > > > >
> > > > > > You're right that the JUnit documentation nee=
ds to be
> improved. As a
> > > > > > volunteer project, we're open to cont=
ributions.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > The following example may serve to addre=
ss the situation you
> raise:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > public class FilterEx=
ample {
> > > > > >   @Test public void runTestsInAList() {
> > > > > >    =
       final String[] tests=3D new String[] {"a", "b"};
> > > > > >        =
   Filter namedTests=3D new Filter() {
> > > > > >                   @Overr=
ide
> > > > > >                   public String describe() {
> > > > > >   =
                        return "only tests starting with
'a'";
> > > > > > =
                  }
> > > > > >                   @Override
> > > > > >    =
               public boolean shouldRun(Description
> description) {
> > > =
> > >                           for (String each : tests)
> > > > > >      =
                             if
> > > > > > (description.getDisplayName().s=
tartsWith(each))
> > > > > >                                           retu=
rn true;
> > > > > >                           return false;
> > > > > >   =
                }
> > > > > >           };
> > > > > >           Request re=
quest=3D
> > > > > > Request.aClass(Tests.class).filterWith(namedTests);
> =
> > > > >           Result result=3D new JUnitCore().run(request);
> > > > =
> >           assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
> > > > > >   }
> > > =
> > >   public static class Tests {
> > > > > >           @Test public void=
 a() {}
> > > > > >           @Test public void b() {}
> > > > > >         =
  @Test public void c() {}
> > > > > >   }
> > > > > > }
> > > > > >
> > > =
> > > Sincerely yours,
> > > > > >

Rivers Institute

=
> > > > > >   Subject: [junit] How to add functionality for execution
> fle=
xibilty?
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > >   I am looking to =
add the following functionality to my tests:
> > > > > >   - When provided =
a list of method names on the command
> line, only
> > > > > > those
> > > =
> > >   methods in the invoked class will be executed.
> > > > > >
> > > > =
> >   I need this implementation at the test class level. This
> was pretty=

> > > > > >   straightforward with JUnit 3.8.1 - just create new
> instanc=
es of the
> > > > > >   derived TestCase with the method name as the argume=
nt, and
> add them
> > > > > > to
> > > > > >   the suite.
> > > > > >
> > =
> > > >   I am having a lot of difficulty trying to replicate this
> > > > =
> >   functionality. The filter logic appears to be a one-shot
> exclusion
=
> > > > > >   filter (everything not matching is dropped), and I can't
> se=
em to
> > > > > > find
> > > > > >   any documentation that would address t=
his.
> > > > > >
> > > > > >   As Mr. Rainsberger and others have suggested=
, I have
> searched the
> > > > > > web
> > > > > >   for an appropriate tu=
torial. I have found a number of good
> basic
> > > > > >   tutorials (incl=
uding some references in this group), and a
> couple
> > > > > > with
> > >=
 > > >   some advanced content. I cannot seem to find one with the
> detail=
 to
> > > > > >   unlock the tools and capabilities that I am positive are
=
> available
> > > > > >   within the new JUnit framework.
> > > > > >
> > >=
 > > >   I am also convinced that no one is as capable as the
> authors in
=
> > > > > >   documenting the features of the framework, and I am having
> =
trouble
> > > > > >   find Javadoc for some of the classes and APIs in the
=
JUnit 4.1
> > > tree.
> > > > > >   There is a fairly good chance that I am=
 looking in the
> wrong place.
> > > > > >
> > > > > >   If anyone has any =
suggestions or guidance on these issues,
> it would
> > > > > > be
> > > > =
> >   greatly appreciated.
> > > > > >
> > > > > >   Thanks in advance!
> >=
